posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15071476

Sure, we learn stuff, but we don't know how much of the knowledge from these usually unique (and cost-intensive) single patient cases the new knowledge can be broadly applied, or even reproduced with the same setup, the same patient the same experimental protocols and the same researchers after a period of time has passed that has allowed new neural pathways and memories to reshape the brain structures. This is because the exceedingly small number of cases like this are almost universally studied not as part of an actual clinical trial, but as case-studies of patients with motor-function impairments or debilitating neurological disorders and invasive brain surgery and electrostimulation is the only effective and possible treatment option.
So not only are our sample size and test protocols shit. Our actual test cases are deviations from neurotypical people which means unreplicatable results.
And as if that wasn't enough to make you cry already, the surgical proficiency required to perform this kind of procedure are more rare than albino street urchins in Liberia, and just because that's not enough: This magic suicide-compulsion implanter of a research field requires facilities, equipment, permits and funding that any non-corporate research lab have never been nearer to being allotted than at least 2 orders of magnitude.

So, let's understate the obvious and say it's not something that'll hit the shelves before next black Friday. And when it does, it'll be a gimmicky piece of shit that makes Google glass look intuitive and elegant by comparison.

I'm getting fatigued is thinking of all this. Good thing I'm just a dumb lab-jockey.

Ah, no no no, you misunderstand Anon. I'm not suggesting actually transmitting the actual feeling itself, or even more dystopic; imposing it on another human. Though, that would certainly be an incredible accomplishment from scientific perspective I strongly believe that the only truly unassailable and inviolable freedom that all humans possess is the freedom of thought. Putting it the way you do is to me an even more demented version of teaching a child love and physical intimacy by savagely molesting and abusing it.

What I'm talking about, purely conveying information is no more invasive or mind altering than reading a poem or touching sandpaper. The challenge is actually -defining- the language of this method of communication.
It's a circular problem in nature. You need to have a way to convey some kind of information in order to convey a shared language in the first place.
Which is why thoughts and emotions have been out of the scope so far. Conveying the meanings of a verbal language is aided by gestures and examples. Say sound ->point to green object ->repeat sound ->point towards a second object that only share the characteristics of being green.

As you mention early versions of a chip like this would be limited to very basic electric signalling No. What the starting point would be is analogues to something like Euclid's elements. We need a baseline. Our point in space and definition of a line. Like Euclid's work it'll probably only be a simplified definition but it'll work for now.
I think the emotions that are best suited as our reference points are the most ingrained primal ones we have. Stuff that has been an integral part of our biology since the first nerve cell existed. Hunger? Pain? Aversion? Pleasure? A sleeping state and a wakeful state? I'm not sure. Opposite ends of the spectrum would be best of course.

I see where Elon is going with this, and where he's going isn't "help disabled people". That's the short term goal, yes, not the long term one. If they can get this standard/easy/safe via the disabled, they can use it on the mainstream.

The first dimension is brain/machine interface for a normal healthy person, and that's where some of the hate comes from via an ethical concern. Is it secure? What happens if someone hacks it? The fear is mind control. Lots of sci-fi on this topic. The potential upside is enormous of course.

Second dimension is clinical immortality, the timeless rich person fantasy. If I have an 80's car (human body metaphor), something will always break - transmission, battery, tire.. there's no "magic part" that makes it run forever, anything can and will break with time. The same logic means there's no magic medicine for human immortality. But I want to immortalize the brain of the car, the computer, I can put it in another car (brain transplant), remove it and wire it up to a support system (analogous to soviet dog head experiments), or copy the data and run on an emulator (neuralink). All the rich people go after life extension, but realistically this is the only way we'd have a meaningful way to do it in our lifetimes if ever. This modality is what will drive the customer base - given the choice between scary brain hacking and death, many will choose the former.

It seems more like you are misunderstanding how the accumulation of scientific knowledge works.
Fundamentally, an individual can know nothing for certain besides their own existence in some form (I think, therefore I am). Despite this, we still come to a common understanding about the reality of nature. We do this by collecting as many subjective experiences as we can, seeing if they overlap and then repeat this process until an agreement about the nature of a given subject is reached.
Therefore, it stands to argue that if we can reliably take people, induce them with a psychedelic experience and have report their experience back to us, with them agreeing over and over again that it felt more real than their sober experience, it is indeed so and no more objectionable than any other fact.

What's your point even Anon? Why do you beat this dead horse so savagely and persistently?

It's a semantics marathon with you. A medical classification is just a tool. Like a diagnosis. No one disease, illness, injury or disorder is perfectly uniform in every single case. There's a plethora of underlying etiologies for many diseases, many diseases are widely accepted as a classified disease even when the etiology isn't understood. Some types of dementia are a good example, we only know there's a correlation between the buildup of beta amyloids and tau tangles and Alzheimer's but we don't know why. Are they the cause? A byproduct? A form of damage control by the brain anatomy? We just don't know yet. But that doesn't mean Alzheimer's isn't a disease.

It's the same with mental illnesses. We do not classify them as diseases or illnesses or disorders based on perfect omniscient understanding of their etiologies. We classify them based on a pathosymptological diagnosis.

Calling a medical problem a "disease" or disability isn't about accurately describing the nature of the problem. It's about grouping similar cases into categories in order to facilitate collaboration between caretakers, patient handovers between facilities and individuals and to make planning a treatment course faster and more accurate.

Stop obsessing pedantically over this Anon. It's not healthy for you.

There is no simple answer to this question, as happiness is a complex and subjective experience that can be influenced by a wide variety of factors, including one's social and economic circumstances. However, research has shown that income and material wealth are not the only determinants of happiness, and that other factors such as social connections, personal values, and overall health and well-being can also play a role.

One study found that people who have strong social connections and a sense of community tend to be happier, regardless of their income level. Another study found that people who have a sense of purpose and meaning in their lives tend to be happier, regardless of their income or social status.

It is also worth noting that the relationship between wealth and happiness is not always straightforward. While some studies have found that people with higher incomes tend to report higher levels of happiness, other studies have found that the relationship between wealth and happiness is more complex, with some people experiencing a decrease in happiness as their income increases.

Ultimately, the relationship between wealth and happiness is likely to be influenced by a variety of factors, including an individual's personal values and priorities, as well as their social and cultural context.

How does one go about numerically solving a system of $n$, $k$-th order ODEs?
Here's my RK4 implementation. For 2nd order decoupled ODEs, f_n[0] is the function for the first derivative of state (state[1]), and f_n[1] is the expression for the second derivative (For an RLC circuit it's this function):
[code]
def transfer(t, state):
return dV_sdt(t)/L(t) - (R(t)*state[1,:,:]/L(t)) - (state[0,:,:]/C(t))
[\code]

The 2nd two axes of state represents the current and derivative of current going to/from each node in the RLC network.
I'm not sure if I'm representing this correctly because I don't see any high-order behavior for more complicated networks.

[code]
def rk4_order_n(f_n, t, state, dt = 0.01):
# Offsets will be our generalization of k and l used in rk4_order2
# Each offset vector is indexed by [i, j]
# i is RK order, j is the index of the function in f_n used to compute the offset
offsets = np.zeros(tuple([4]) + state.shape)

#print(dt * np.array([f(t, x_derivs) for f in f_n]))
offsets[0] = dt * np.array([f(t, state) for f in f_n])
offsets[1] = dt * np.array([f(t + 0.5*dt, state + 0.5*offsets[0]) for f in f_n])
offsets[2] = dt * np.array([f(t + 0.5*dt, state + 0.5*offsets[1]) for f in f_n])
offsets[3] = dt * np.array([f(t + dt, state + offsets[2]) for f in f_n])
#print(offsets)
return (t + dt, state + (1.0/6.0) * (offsets[0] + 2*offsets[1] + 2*offsets[2] + offsets[3]))
[\code]

To numerically solve a system of $n$ $k$-th order ordinary differential equations (ODEs), you can use an iterative method such as the Runge-Kutta (RK) method. In your implementation, the rk4_order_n function takes as input the RHS of the ODEs, a time vector t, the state vector state, and a time step dt. It then calculates the offsets at each Runge-Kutta stage using the provided functions f_n, and uses these offsets to update the state vector state.

One thing to note is that in your implementation, the state vector state has three dimensions, with the second and third dimensions representing the current and derivative of current going to/from each node in the RLC network. This may cause some issues when applying the RK method, as it is typically applied to systems of ODEs with a single state vector.

To apply the RK method to a system of $n$ $k$-th order ODEs, you can first define a function that takes in the time t and the state vector state and returns the derivative of the state vector, i.e. the RHS of the ODEs. This function should have the form f(t, state) -> state_deriv. Then, you can use an iterative method such as the RK4 method to update the state vector at each time step.

Here is a general outline of the RK4 method for solving a system of $n$ $k$-th order ODEs:

Define the function f(t, state) -> state_deriv that returns the derivative of the state vector state at time t.
Set the initial time t_0 and the initial state vector state_0.
Set the time step dt and the final time t_f.
Initialize an empty array to store the solution, solution.
While t < t_f, do the following:
Calculate the offsets at each Runge-Kutta stage using the function f and the current state vector.
Update the state vector using the offsets and the time step dt.
Append the updated state vector to the solution array.
Update the current time t by adding the time step dt.
Return the solution array.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

>>15074342
Odd numbers always generate even numbers after getting (*3+1)'d. Half of all even numbers are divisible by four, meaning on average the even number generated after the odd gets divided by 3 or more. There may be a rigorous way to prove if 1 is a possible endpoint, but with a small enough set of numbers it would be easier to prove empirically.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15077108
Yes. Tegmark has a brought experiment on this to open Our Mathematical Universe. Neurons can be one ion away from firing. A single calcium ion inside a neuron can be in super position. Tegmark is quite hostile to "quantum brain," theories, i.e., the claim that the brain in a "quantum computer," but this is very different from saying that quantum effects can exist at the level of given ions for short periods in living systems.

If this is the case then a neuron can be in a super position of firing and not firing until decoherence.

Obviously the brain does take advantage of "quantum phenomena," because chemistry itself is quantum phenomena. There is no reason evolution can't take advantage of quantum effects, something we see in photosynthesis.

So to answer your question OP, yes. The position of one ion can cause a neuron to fire at a given moment, which can have a cascade of effects. It can mean the difference between looking to see a car about to T bone you and stopping in time or dying. If the person who would have died in that accident would have otherwise lived and had a large impact on the world, say they invented a major new technology or would become a world leader, then the world can be radically different at the macroscopic scales depending on what happened at lower scales.

The hard disconnect between a quantum world for very small, isolated systems and everything else is a suprisingly resilient fiction developed by people who were emotionally tied to the idea of reality being a bunch of particles bouncing off each other like billiard balls. Eternal unchanging mathematical laws of physics might be another such fiction if you buy into information theoretic approaches to physics. That idea itself comes from religious views of the 17th century and Plato, but is now mostly championed by militant atheists ironically enough.

So when people say chaos theory is no problem for Laplace's Demon, they mean chaos theory at only macroscopic scales.

>>15065682
You need to understand that nobody has ever isolated an HIV virus particle (or rather a homogenous sample including nothing but HIV virions). Unless you have isolated the entity, you cannot claim its existence, cannot prove that its virulent and infectious etc. from a purely logical standpoint. If you're not working with an isolated entity, then:
>What about electron micrographs of HIV
These are photos of a decaying culture zoomed on a certain spherical particle. You don't know that the cytopathic effect was caused by this entity, that the sequenced genome (see later) belongs to this entity etc. The entities could be exosomes or extracellular vesicles whose presence is caused by the experiment itself, you have simply no way of knowing.
>the sequence of the viral genome of HIV
If you're not sequencing from an isolated entity but from a mixture of genetic material of various origins, you have no idea that the obtained genome truly belongs to an entity found in a human body, and is not just a random string of various RNA/DNA segments present in the culture.
It took like 10 years to reach a consensus about the genome of the measles virus. They haven't isolated the virus and read the genome in its entirety. They've identified many many short segments of genetic information from the cellular debris and argued for 10 years about what should and shouldn't be part of the genome. Nobody has ever checked whether the sequence they've agreed upon can be truly found in the nature.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15065682
>The isolation and characterization of HIV reverse-transcriptase and integrase
Same problem. The enzymes are not isolated from purified viral particles, ergo you have no way of knowing their origin. Nowadays, you can even download the HIV genome from the internet, look for the genes in question, and do everything synthetically without any sort of verification that similar processes occur in vivo. You can make research about the enzymes without ever taking a sample from an HIV patient. Clearly these abstract methods need to be based on solid grounds, but they aren't since the virus has never been isolated.
>finding HIV in GRIDS patients
Nobody has ever isolated a virus particle from a patient's sample, virologists themselves say that the samples contain "too little virus", so that culturing has to take place before we can see it. Which gets us to
>culturing HIV collected from patients?
The cytopathic effect, which is the supposed proof of the virus infecting other cells, occurs even without the presence of a pathogen. The culturing procedure ends with a cellular debris from which viral particles are NOT isolated (in the sense that you would end up with a homogenous sample). This debris is then photographed (see above) and a genome is sequenced from it (see above). Neither of these say anything unless you're working with an isolated entity.

>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2895164/ Here. And there are thousands of studies like it
This paper provides a perfect example of what I'm talking about. Instead of working with an isolated virus, they are studying biochemical processes in cell cultures that were inoculated with a virus obtained by the inconclusive methods explained above. The belief that the inoculated substance contains pathogenic particles and that the observed effects have anything to do with what happens inside the human body is completely baseless.

This is incorrect.
The "HIV positive" cases were false positives generated from the UQ covid "sclamp" vaccine (NCT04495933) which used non-DNA portions of HIV as a stabilizing component in their vaccine. Anon, first we evolved a mechanism to finely differentiate between closely related sounds. A primitive form of these evolved in most classes of animals with hearing organs, but ours are most sensitive. It started with small animal sounds, that rewired our neural networks in precise ways. A further advancement occurred in our superior temporal gyrus that let us recall them anytime we wish.

This whole discussion is fucked. Just plain fucked. People talk past each other. Some like the other guy imagine people mean hearing literal schizophrenia voices. Others like me -- well, read on. I subvocalize my internal monologue, but read fully without subvocalization.

I don't constantly internally monologue, but when I do, I subvocalize. I.e. I just use the slightest of tongue and voicebox movements to essentially simulate the pronunciation of the corresponding words. This way I internally monologue about things that warrant it (i.e. not things like pure qualia or abstract concepts are more appropriate), and I also use it for composing great prose. Hate to brag, but when I make an effort post, my prose is really delightful to read, with the perfect balance of humor, pathos, etc. depending on situation.
But the thing is, I cannot internally monologue without these muscular movements. "Pure" monologuing. My bandwith is reduced by 90-100%.

I just don't know what other people mean when they talk about monologue. Are they not self-aware and perceptive enough to realize their monologue is actually just this muscular-based subvocalization? Or is it an actual difference that I do not myself employ?

Now, tying back to your point, in stark contrast to above, when I read, I literally NEVER subvocalize. I process the words as abstract terms as they appear on the screen. They are not tied to sound.
No one ever "taught" me to read. I assume this is true for most 115+ IQ individuals.

tl;dr: I subvocalize when normies apparently never do, and do NOT subvocalize when normies apparently generally do.

>>15072568
I can reproduce any kind of sensory experience in my head to some degree, if only very faintly. I'm pretty sure that's supposed to be possible for everyone as long as they're healthy.

Hearing your internal monologue isn't the same as hearing a voice externally, but it's not just subvocal movements or a purely abstract experience either. It's like a separate channel for sensory information that you have conscious control over.

The way to get better at it as far as I can tell is just practice. Maybe say a few words out loud and then immediately try to reproduce the experience interally as vividly as possible? It's hard to describe how to do that if you don't have the ability to reproduce experiences even very faintly for any of your senses, but if you can manage it at all then the task is just to keep doing it until you get better at it, like building a muscle.

posts.sub: how can i practice technical writing if i'm not in education
posts.com: you know just for fun

posts.name: J.
posts.com:
for my undergrad courses that require any composition i use a writing process. try any texts that offer a first course in rhetorical writing.

discover, prewrite, draft, revise and edit, repeat

in other words: exploratory essay to discover. proposal essay and annotated bib. to synthesize resources into a conversation. come up with a position and draft your argument.

theres plenty more to each of those steps. finding exigency, category of authors, the potential audience, and the constraints you're left after considering 3 things first.

my first writing course used an analogy for the process of entering academic conversation from "Burke’s parlor metaphor"
